msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 230/116

msDesc.head: Compilation of texts from St Albans

summary.seg: This vast compilation of theological, devotional, historical, scientific, and medical texts in Latin and Middle English prose and verse was copied in the 15th century at the Benedictine abbey at St Albans, Herefordshire. The manuscript has been tentatively identified in a list of books that were made for the monastery's library during the abbacy of John Whethamstede (1420-1440 and 1451-65) (see CBMLC 4 (1996), p. 569 [B.88 no. 30]; and 'Miscellanea theologica (Theological excerpts, formulae, etc.'), in MLGB3 (accessed 23 June 2023)). This is also confirmed by the manuscript's contents: among these are nine excerpts from Whethamstede's Granarium (e.g. p. 154) [see Hiatt (2014), p. 16 n. 13], and a selection of his poems and letters (pp. 117-127; 179-180; 191-192; 222-227; 311). The manuscript also contains one of the three extant copies of the Tractatus Horologii Astronomici, a work of 1327 by Richard Wallingford (1292–1336), abbot of St Albans, which describes the workings of his renowned astronomical clock (pp. 30-36); and epitaphs of Thomas de la Mere (1309-1396), abbot of St Albans (p. 202), and John Bernwell (d. 1400), who was buried in St Peter's Church, St Albans (p. 135).

In cataloguing this manuscript, moreover, there has been discovered a previously unknown, unfinished copy of the metrical life of St Alban by Ralph of Dunstable [Ralph of St Albans] (fl. 1180?), a monk of St Albans (pp. 321-324). This adds another witness to the surviving copies of Ralph of Dunstable’s work (which until now had only been identified in three medieval manuscripts) and further strengthens the St Albans provenance of this manuscript [On Dunstable, see Bateson (1885), p. 218; McLeod (1980), pp. 412, 414 fn. 13].

Several previously unnoticed short instructional texts have come to light as well. These include sequences of prayers that are either directly derived from or based on the revelations of the Benedictine nun Mechtild of Hackeborn (1240/1241–1298), as recorded by two of her sisters in religion in the Liber Specialis Gratiae (see pp. 334; 334-335; 335-336; 338-339); a macaronic (Latin-Middle English) medical recipe (p. 162) and a method for keeping ink from freezing (p. 177); and an encrypted Latin text that describes a magical method to establish how many sexual partners a woman has had (p. 314).

Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

foliation.note: Numbering in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

One leaf after pp. 163-164 omitted from pagination sequence and one leaf after pp. 209-210 accidentally numbered 209-210. For the purposes of producing a functional electronic catalogue record for the volume as part of the Curious Cures project, these leaves have been assigned page numbers in square brackets: pp. [164a-164b] and [210a-210b] respectively.
Pagination skips from p. 292 to p. 303.
Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

signatures.p: Arabic numerals in pencil added by a modern hand to the right-hand lower corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: Blind-stamped and -tooled brown leather binding over wooden boards made by J.P. Gray and Son, Cambridge, 1909 (see the stamp on the inside of the front cover).

provenance.p: William Moore (1590-1659) Moore, William, 1590-1659, BA, MA, fellow of and lecturer in rhetoric at Gonville and Caius College, and librarian of Cambridge University Library.

history.acquisition: Given or bequeathed by William Moore to Gonville and Caius College in 1659: its armorial bookplate pasted on the inside of the upper cover, inscribed with the classmark numbers '116' (red ink) and '230' (brown ink); number 1135 in the catalogue of the College's manuscripts in Edward Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry partly draws on M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Gonville and Caius College, vol. 2 (Cambridge, 1908); and Kari Anne Rand Schmidt, Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Brewer, 2001).

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

supportDesc.collation: Two sets of four leaves, each of which has been cut out of a larger leaf from another manuscript and bound into this manuscript.

layout.seg: No ruling. Because the leaves originate from a larger leaf that has been cut up, it is impossible to give accurate details about the dimensions of the text space or number of lines.

handNote.p: Copied in a 14th-century hand in a Northern Textualis script.

Small (1 line) initials in blue or red ink.

msItem.title: Inscription in St Augustine's table

msItem.title: Six votive masses for the souls in Purgatory
msItem.rubric: 43-44 Rubrica de sex missis quarum quinque debent legi de sancta Cruce et una de Resurrectione domin. Quas si quis cum deuota intentione pro anima alicuius in purgatorio existente legerit seu legi fecerit; eciam si in diem nouissimum puniri debeat liberabitur. Quod egregius doctor de ordine minorum in sermone publico predicauit. Eundem vero sermonem due matrone honeste audientes promiserunt vt vna pro alia que prius moreretur predictas sex missas ordinare deberet. Quod et factum est. mortua autem vna et missis pro ea lectis; reuersa anima in tanta claritate apparuit ; quid alia superstes pre nimio gaudes tribus diebus sine omni refectione cibi et potus permansit [...] Et iste sex misse semper sunt incipiende feria tercia
msItem.incipit: 44-45 Oracio prima feria .iij.a: Domine ihesu Christe fili dei unu rogo te per innocentem captiuitatem quam pro nobis et pro omni genera humano sustinuisti vt digneris liberare animam .N. ab omni captiuitate a pena purgatorij
msItem.explicit: 46 Oracio sexta dominica die .i. de Resurrectione: Domine ihesu Christe unu rogo te pro gloriosa resurrectione qua potenter resurrexisti . vt animam .N. tecum sic facias resurgere ; vt ipsa a te numquam separetur. Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription of the rubric and indulgence; this is followed by an exemplum about a soul who is released from Purgatory after requesting the six masses from a Cistercian monk and futher instructions relating to performing the six masses.

msItem.title: Form for absolution

msItem.title: Tract on the geography of the world excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 59 Terram nostram habitabit videlicet illa quam autor nature eleuauit
msItem.explicit: 66 ad secundam partem Granarii magistri Iohannis Abbatis Albanensis de historiis et historiographis plenair informandus recurrat
msItem.note: The tract discusses the different subdivisions of the world into seven regions governed by different planets, seven climatic zones, and three landmasses (Africa, Asia, and Europe), referring to Al-Farghani ('Alfraganus'), Ptolemy, Pliny, Solinus, Isidore, and John de Whethamstede's Granarium.

msItem.incipit: 113 Wyth laude and prys my soule magnifieth / Eternal lord bothe oon two and thre
msItem.explicit: 116 he heath maade mercy oure kynde to restore / And of all his werkis to be souereyne .J. Lydgate
msItem.note: Here attributed to John Lydgate.

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Richard I
msItem.incipit: 116 Pictauis exta ducis ; sepelit . tellusque chalucis
msItem.explicit: 116 Nec fuit hoc fumus cui sufficeret locus vnus

msItem.title: Epitaph of King John
msItem.incipit: 118 Hoc in sacrophago ; sepelitur regis ymago
msItem.explicit: 118 discute quid rerum ; pariat tibi meta dierum

msItem.title: Epitaph of Richard Marsh, Bishop of Durham
msItem.rubric: 118 Epitaphium Ricardi de Mariscoo Episcopi dunelmensis
msItem.incipit: 118 Culmina qui cupitis laudes pompasque scititis
msItem.explicit: 118 Quod sum vos eritis ad me currendo venitis

msItem.title: Poem for the archdeacon
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 117 Versus exhortatorii dom. J. Albanensis ad suum archidiaconum
117 Qui causas regitis et lites soluere scitis
msItem.explicit: 118 vertit et interdum ; libramen iudiciorum etcaetera

msItem.title: Letter in verse
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 118 Epistola increpetoria eiusdem domini cuidam metrice
118 Pagina multiplicem tibi dicit amice salutem
msItem.explicit: 119 Sexta scripta die ; post nuncia sancta marie etcaetera

msItem.title: Poem on family
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.rubric: 119 Eiusdem domini etcaetera de suis Auunculis
msItem.incipit: 119 Nominis eiusdem tres lactabantur ibidem / Quo fluit in pelagus tyna recens fluuius / Clauiger unus erat. prior alter et hic sacer extat / Tercius Albani pastor prothomartiris almi / Hiis tribus hoc unum frumenti dant loca nomen Whethamstede
msItem.explicit: 121 Precepto domini cui constat vinea celi

msItem.title: Poems against violaters of his writings
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 122 Terra sibi fruges amnis sibi deneget undas
msItem.explicit: 122 Aut in nunc alium quam scribitur applicat usum

msItem.title: Poem against the Bishop of Norwich
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 122 Pastor magnifice vellem te magnificare
msItem.explicit: 125 Vincere de tanto qui fecit nos munico

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 125 Rex detestatur quod index pars habeatur / Sed tu Radulphe pudeat quod es unus uterque
msItem.explicit: 126 Sicque tui sterilis est sillaba nominis omnis

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 127 Jynius [sic] es dictus iuuenum mensi similaris
msItem.explicit: 127 Justiciam varies mox ramis r[...] fies

msItem.title: Poem on Damasus
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 127 Qui gradiens pelagi fluctus compressit amaros
msItem.explicit: 127 faciat quod surgem credo

msItem.title: Tract on the precedence of England over France excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 128 Nacio etcaetera Sicque in hoc sacro Constantiensi concilio et continue deinceps vsque ad tempora consilij Basiliensis de scisa
msItem.explicit: 130 concipientesque motina malicie obiciebant in annullacionem sui honoris sub huius verborum tenore

msItem.title: Letter of King Abgar to Jesus
msItem.rubric: 130 Epistola Abigari regis ad dominum Ihesum - Papa Benedictus et s. vt s.
msItem.incipit: 131 Abagarus vchanie filius thoparca; Jhesu saluatori bono qui apparuit in locis Jherusolimorum salutem
msItem.explicit: 131 Est autem ciuitas michi parua sed honesta que sufficiat vtrisque. Vale.

msItem.title: Letter of Jesus to King Abgar
msItem.incipit: 131 Beatus es qui credidisti in me
msItem.explicit: 131 Cum ergo fuero assumptus ; mittam tibi aliquem ex discipulis meis vt curet egritudinem tuam et uitam tibi atque hijs qui tecum sunt prestet

msItem.title: Letter of Philip, Abbot of Val Sainte-Marie, to Helinand of Froidmont
msItem.rubric: Epistola philippi abbatis de valle ad Helinandum historicum
msItem.incipit: 131 Filio helinando philippus abbas salutem
msItem.explicit: 132 et sonitus fauorum ac gloriam auribus semper eorum. Vale

msItem.title: Arithmetical poem
msItem.incipit: 132 Quadrantes sabbato quot nos expendimus vno / Tot crescunt solidi cum tot nummis numerati
msItem.explicit: 132 Proque die solo qui restat ; septima a pars sit / Dat sabbati quadrans numinum solidumque per annum

msItem.title: Poem on death
msItem.incipit: 132 Cum mors sit ceca ; videt omnes omnibus equa
msItem.explicit: 132 Mors domat indomitos ; nil pietatis habens

msItem.title: Epitaph for Petrus Comestor
msItem.incipit: 134 Petrus eram quem petra tegit dictusque comestor
msItem.explicit: 135 Quod sumus iste fuit; erimus quandoque quod hic est

msItem.title: Epitaph for John Bernwell (d. 1400) in St Peter's Church, St Albans
msItem.incipit: 135 Dummodo vixisti quia spemque fidem tenuisti
msItem.explicit: 135 Sit Bernwelt [sic: Bernwell] prima ; mors et tua vita secunda
msItem.note: The epitaph is reprodcued in Weever (1631), p. 581

msItem.title: Littera pro promotione prioris ad Episcopum diocesanum
Poem extracted from Petrus Riga's Aurora
msItem.author: Petrus Riga
msItem.incipit: 138 Heu puer ille color meus est dolor illa figura
msItem.explicit: 138 De puero puri cum sene flete senescum sene flete senes

msItem.title: Tract on the Earthly Paradise excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 139 Paradisus locus est deliciosus a nostro secretus
msItem.explicit: 144 si non per preuaricacionem incidisset in peccatum
msItem.note: The tract refers to the Letter of Aristotle to Alexander the Great.

msItem.title: Model letter
msItem.note: The letter is made for the Diocese of Lincoln.

msItem.title: Oration
msItem.incipit: 147 Protector pauperum oppressorumque adiutor
msItem.explicit: 146 procellas silueruntque fluctus eius. Scriptus etcaetera
msItem.note: The oration, which refers to the Bishop of Norwich, begins on p. 147 and ends with the Greek letter Phi (φ) and the note: 'in alia parte'. The second part of the speech appears to be marked with the same letter at the top of p. 146.

msItem.title: Verse from Domitian 23.2
msItem.author: Suetonius
msItem.incipit: 146 Nuper Tarpeio qui sedit culmine cornix
msItem.explicit: 146 Est bene non potuit dicere . dixit erit.

msItem.title: Epitaph of St Avitus of Vienne
msItem.incipit: 146 Unus in arce fuit qui quolibet ordine fandi
msItem.explicit: 146 Qui vixit viuit ; perque omnia secula vivet

msItem.title: Two untitled model letters
msItem.note: Both letters are written for the Diocese of Lincoln.

msItem.title: Verse riddle from the Secretum philosophorum
msItem.incipit: 151 Prima triangula longa subambula curta sequatur / Greca sit vltima pede penultima talis amatur
msItem.note: Full transcription, see Galloway (1995), p. 102.

msItem.title: Verse riddle from the Secretum philosophorum
msItem.incipit: 151 ffilia sum solis et sum sine sole creata / Sum quinquaginta sum quindecim atque vocata - Lux
msItem.note: Full transcription, see Galloway (1995), p. 102.

msItem.title: Poem in praise of England
msItem.incipit: 151 Anglia terra ferax et fertilis angulus orbis
msItem.explicit: 152 Sed lingua melior liberiorque manus.
msItem.note: Eulogistic verses on England beginning with a phrase from Hildebert of Tours, PL 171:1443-44.

msItem.title: Poem on the foundation of Verona
msItem.author: Godfrey [Geoffrey] of Viterbo
msItem.rubric: 152 De fundatione ciuitatis verone - Godfredus viterbiensis
msItem.incipit: 152 Dum furit in armis ; fundat dux Brenno veronam
msItem.explicit: 152 Nam quasi veroma dicta verona sonat

msItem.title: Poem on popes Boniface III and IV
msItem.author: Godfrey [Geoffrey] of Viterbo
msItem.incipit: 152 Tercius est papa bonefacius ille benignus
msItem.explicit: 152 Primaque demonij tunc manet aula dei

msItem.title: Poem in praise of England
msItem.author: Alfred of Beverley
msItem.incipit: 154 Anglia etcaetera Glebis lacte fanis supereminet insula cunctis / Insula stat dives quae toto non eget orbe . Et cuius totus etcaetera
msItem.finalRubric: 154 vide in folio precedente et istum versum et primum
msItem.note: Full transcription, with reference to the poem in praise of England on p. 151 for the full versions of the first and last line.

The poem also features in John Whethampstede's Granarium (see London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero C VI) where it is attributed to Alfred of Beverley's Historia de gestis regalibus regum Britanniae.

msItem.title: Poem on Christ's blood
msItem.incipit: 154 Vnda fluens aqua praeteriens aqua mixta lieo / Est Christi caro Christo sanguine inuictus homo
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem on the Virgin Mary from the Pantheon
msItem.author: Godfrey [Geoffrey] of Viterbo
msItem.rubric: 154 Hoc Godfredus Viterbiensis de sancta Anna Joachim de sponsata
msItem.incipit: 154 Femina quod queris domino donante mereris
msItem.explicit: 154 Nomine messias: spes bona vita via

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Henry II
msItem.incipit: 156 Sufficit hic tumulus cui vix suffecerat orbis
msItem.explicit: 156 Humane speculum conditionis habe

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Henry II (?)
msItem.incipit: 156 O dolor o plusquam dolor . heu sunt gaudia nusquam
msItem.explicit: 157 Sed quia mors nullum patitur post fata regressum

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Henry V
msItem.incipit: 157 Ad vitam lacrime si sufficient reuocare
msItem.explicit: 157 Horreat horrorem sic vinat rex in id ipsum .Amen.

msItem.title: Lamentation of the Lord of St Albans upon the death of King Henry V
msItem.rubric: 157 Deploratio domini I Albanensis super morte .h. .v.ti reg. angl.
msItem.incipit: 157 Anglicus angelus est . cui semper credere fas est / Angelicum vultum fert a Christo sibi dultum
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Edward I
msItem.rubric: 157 De Eduuardo primo quidam sic metrice scripsit
msItem.incipit: 157 Dum vignit [sic] rex et valuit tua magna potestas / ffraus latuit pax magna fuit regnauit honestas
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Berengar of Tours
msItem.rubric: 157 Hildebertus episcopus de Berengario contra quem scripsit Lanfrancus
msItem.incipit: 157 Quem modo miramur semper mirabitur orbis
msItem.explicit: 157 Nec melior fiat sors mea sorte sua
msItem.note: The same verse with the attribution to Lanfranc of Bec is found in Ranulf Higden's Polychronicon.

msItem.title: Four riddles
msItem.incipit: 158 Sum nimis ampla domus eternum sentio fumum / Si mihi b rapias de terris extraho dumum.
msItem.explicit: 158 Fecundans matrem natam genui sed ab illa / Natum cui mater natus fraterque nepos es
msItem.note: The riddles have been fully transcribed in Galloway (1995), p. 102.

msItem.title: Dialogue between a porter and a traveller
msItem.incipit: 158 Pande fores . Quare; Iubeo . non audio iussum
msItem.explicit: 158 Intra te nosco . Tibi pareo. verna tuus sum
msItem.note: The text has been fully transcribed in Galloway (1995), p. 102.

msItem.title: Two verses on Mohammed
msItem.incipit: 158 Te pariunt sternit vorat impie toxica morbis
msItem.explicit: 158 Audiuro cessa vena vel nare repressa . dicitur t. et totiens pater noster

msItem.title: Unidentified medical tracts relating to the heart
msItem.incipit: 159 Ad cordulandam torqu[?e]atam cordam
msItem.explicit: 162 arcum suum singulerem sinistre manus

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Recipes pro oculis, pro pice, pro ca[?l]culo, and for the piles.
These items are not listed in Rand Schmidt (2001).

msItem.title: Theological tract on Christ's body
msItem.incipit: 163 Tribus de causis precipue reseruauit dominus cicatrices in corpore licet incorruptibili
msItem.explicit: 163 dicit tum Bede quod corpus domini subtile erat per effectum spiritualis potentie et palpabile per vitatem nature vt vitatem carnis probaret

msItem.author: Quintus Curtius Rufus
msItem.title: Tract on Alexander the Great's conduct from the Historia Alexandri Magni
msItem.incipit: 163 Erat enim adolescens indolis supra vires humanas preclare et animi virtute precellens
msItem.explicit: 164 Spreto mortali habitu diuinum emulatus est; nec suis magis odibilis quod patrem quod ciuem quod hominem demum exuere pudori non erat

msItem.title: Treatise on the Signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 165 In nomine unu patris domini nostri ihesu Christi. Accipe aurum purissimum et fundatur sole intrante Arietem, scilicet iij kalendas Aprilis
msItem.explicit: 168 et contra omnia apostemata et ad multa alia et portetur in renibus
msItem.note: A early printed version of the same text (there called "Sigilla magistri Arnaldi de Villa nova") has been reproduced in Germain (1872), pp. 15-17.

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.incipit: 168 Ysidoris hispaliensis Origenem deplangens
msItem.explicit: 168 His me collectum: [...]pia tela preniunt

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 168 Recipium ff[...]tre scabiose horehone et Isopi
msItem.explicit: 168 et postea addatur pinta melle etcaetera

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 168 Ad spissitudinemnem .ca. fero iij. cap .mane gri. iii coclear.
msItem.note: Only the recipe's rubric is present due to the loss of the next four leaves.

msItem.author: Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours [Hildebert of Lavardin]
msItem.title: Poem on the monuments of Rome
msItem.rubric: 169 Hildebertus de rome ruina sic metrice scribit
msItem.incipit: 169 Par tibi roma nichil ; cum sis pene tota ruina / ffracta docere potes; integra quanta fores
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Treatise on charters excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 169 In primis sciendum est quid sit carta; Carta est quoddam feoffamentum siue scriptum sigillatum de re immobili data cum pacifica seisma
msItem.explicit: 176 post datam carte videlicet per vnum , duos ; vel tres dies debet ordinari

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 177 Aborsus: Suctus centauree
msItem.explicit: 177 et sic donec tota materia conversa sit in aqua et sic habebit aquam mour.

msItem.title: Recipe to keep ink from freezing
msItem.rubric: 177 To kepe blak ynke from fresyng
msItem.incipit: 177 Put þe quantite of a pest ful of Caumfer to a galon pot of ynke and it schal neuer frese
msItem.note: This item is not listed in Rand Schmidt (2001).

msItem.title: Tract on determining the Dominical Letters for the year 1412
msItem.incipit: 178 Si vis inuenire litteram dominicale primo incipies infra anulum ad annum domini .M. CCCC. xij. sic oblique script. ad finem eiusdem .D.
msItem.explicit: 178 tunc deme de diebus quot sunt ab .a. vsque ad finem

msItem.title: Tract on determining the Sun and Moon conjunctions for any particular year
msItem.incipit: 179 Si vis scire coniunctiones solis et lune orte habere radicem semel in anno pro quocumque anno valueris habere
msItem.explicit: 179 et illid quod remanet est [...] illius meus

msItem.title: Letter from John Whethamstede to Syon Abbey
msItem.incipit: 179 Salutem in hujus visceribus Lathomi qui dat gratiam coedificandi habitaculum spiritus sancti

msItem.title: Epigram
msItem.incipit: 180 Pauper languentes non pectant bis comedentes / Praegnans vexati, peragrans puer inuetati
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verse
msItem.incipit: 180 Lagana listrigone laurino lita liquore ; / lites linores litigia longa labores
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Sermon on Ephesians 3
msItem.incipit: 181 Ambulate ad Eph. iiio. fforsake youre synne þat doon a mys and sue þe weye þat ledeth to blis
msItem.explicit: 181 Nota est de loco Indie qui retinet omnem ferrum cum [...]
msItem.note: After the Middle English in the incipit, the rest of the sermon is in Latin.
This item is not listed in Rand Schmidt (2001).

msItem.title: Sermon on Canticles 2
msItem.incipit: 182 Vinee florentes odorem dederunt. Cant. 2o.
msItem.explicit: 183 perfidie lyrenas audijt nec accessit

msItem.title: Poems attributed to Godfrey of Viterbo
msItem.incipit: 183 Credite vos senones ; nobis deus ista parauit
msItem.explicit: 183 Idem de fundatione mediolam: Sus erat in medio lanoso vellere tergo / A vario tergo dux Brennius intulit ergo / Hec mediolani nomen habebit ait

msItem.title: Tract on the wonders of the world excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 184 Inter alia orbis mirabilia hoc habet admiracione dignum paphos veneris quod in ipsius area nunquam cadit pluuialis aqua
msItem.explicit: 191 vide cum fictionis veritate in supra deo ysidoro libro .iio. cao. 3o. bene vltra medium.

msItem.title: Letter from (?) John Whethamstede to (?) Bishop William Alnwick
msItem.incipit: 191 Johannes miseracione etcaetera Willelmo etcatera

msItem.title: Poem on the corruption of age
msItem.incipit: 193 Vox in rama resonat plorantis rachelis / Et peremptos eiulat natos israelis
msItem.explicit: 202 Hinc est theorema / Si cartam infregeris feres anathema. Amen

msItem.title: Epitaph of Thomas de la Mere (1309-1396), Abbot of St Albans
msItem.incipit: 202 Occidit anglorum sol illustris monachorum / Qui dum vinebat in aurum benedictus habebat
msItem.explicit: 202 fflete super funus quia non est par suus vnus

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.incipit: 202 Omnia sunt homini tenui pendencia filo
msItem.explicit: 202 Nunc stat et obstat homo flat et efflat floret et aret / Incipit et teritur stant ea pene simul

msItem.title: Astrological treatise
msItem.rubric: 202 Incipit tractatus qui dicitur Cavete medici
msItem.incipit: 202 Quando sol est in illis duobus punctis
msItem.explicit: 221 pertinent ad occultacionem
msItem.note: Another copy is extant in London, British Library, Arundel MS 11.

msItem.title: Poem (by John Whethamstede?)
msItem.incipit: 222 Promite pierides si dulce quid est eliconi
msItem.explicit: 223 Emendet lector que male scripta legit

msItem.title: Poem (by John Whethamstede?)
msItem.incipit: 223 Simonis esto uia rogo semper uirgo maria
msItem.explicit: 223 Quicquid agam socia sis michi uirgo pia

msItem.title: Poem (by John Whethamstede?)
msItem.incipit: 223 Felix qui nouit alienos cernere casus
msItem.explicit: 225 Et sic nolle nephas est quoque velle salus

msItem.title: Poem (by John Whethamstede?)
msItem.incipit: 225 Ue tibi mi ciate veniens since concauitate
msItem.explicit: 227 Quando conualuit prauus ut ante fuit

msItem.title: Moral distichs
msItem.incipit: 227 fflamen nate pater assis michi diaque mater / Et simon caule domini dux docteque paule / Mentem verba manum nichil inquinet oro prophanum / Sensum veri victum finem quoque des benedictum
msItem.explicit: 227 Quando languebat, agnus lupus esse volebat . / Quando convaluit, pranus vt ante fuit

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: 227 Cani sunt sensus hominis sapiencie .4. capitulo et in espistola quam hodie in emmoriam passionis sancti prothomartirum anglorum albani sua et suorum monachorum legit ecclesia
msItem.explicit: 250-251 in qua sensus ab excellenti non ledetur sensibili et intellectus a super excellenti intellecti beatificandus copulabitur ipsi deo. Ad quem nos perducat qui sine fine viuit et regnat. Amen

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are headed Pro arsura and Pro frenesi.

msItem.title: Verse
msItem.incipit: 251 Pax tibi roma nichil cum sis pene tota ruma / ffracta docere potes ; integra quanta fores
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Treatise on Papal power excerpted from the Granarium
msItem.author: John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 251 Papa presidens suppremus in ecclesia
msItem.explicit: 270 Hec omnia colligi potuerunt ex autoribus supernis allegatur hinc inde sparsim in suis locis
msItem.note: The text includes references to the Italian Augustinian friars Alexander of San Elpidio (1269–1326) [Alexander de helpidio] and Augustinus Triumpus (1243–1328) [Augustinus de Anchona], Dante Alighieri's (1265–1321) De Monarchia [Dans de monarchia mundi], Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274)'s De potestate regia et papali [Thomas de potestate papali]; Alvarus Pelagius (c. 1280–1352) [Aluarus de planctu ecclesie]; and a work by Marsilius of Padua (1270–1342) [Marsilius de ecclesiastica potestate].

msItem.title: Treatise on the five parts of the Church
msItem.incipit: 270 Nacio. Quemadmodum in primis nascentis temporibus sancta mater ecclesia in membra quinque fuerat sinodaliter principaliterque subdiuisa
msItem.explicit: 284 ne ipse forsan iterum in sui ignominiam sputum proprium reglutire

msItem.title: Treatise on herbs (organised alphabetically)
msItem.incipit: 284 Inter herbas absinthium virtutes fertur habere contrarius laxatiuam videlicet constrictivam
msItem.explicit: 303 Zizannia vero herba tritico multum nocina vnu habet ventoasam et quodammodo venenosam; et ideo cito in ebriatis caput leditur

msItem.title: Two verses
msItem.incipit: 306 Non vt adoretur fit ymago sed vt ueneretur / ffactorem factura suum qui cuncta creauit. Rusticus in luna quem sarcina detinet vna / Monstrat per spinas nulli prodesse rapinas.
msItem.note: The verses have been written below a large circular diagram drawn in red ink.

msItem.title: Astronmical poem (accompanying the unfinished diagram on p. 306)
msItem.incipit: 307 Versibus hijs breuibus presentem pinge figuram
msItem.explicit: 307 Tunc F. descendat ; quam recta G.J.K. rescundat; ET .K. dico fore; punctum quam credimus hore

msItem.title: Astronomical poem (accompanying the unfinished diagram on p. 306)
msItem.incipit: 307 Si non directe paries stest adhuc operare
msItem.explicit: 307 Nec plus matura ; sibi vult hec nostra figura. finis

msItem.title: Poem on King Edward I
msItem.incipit: 307 Dum vigint rex ; et valuit tua magna potestas / Fraus latuit pax magna fuit regnauit honestas
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Epitaph
msItem.incipit: 309 Pontificalis apex; virtutum pondere plenis
msItem.explicit: 309 Formula virtutum; cui tua vita fuit

msItem.title: Epitaph
msItem.incipit: 309 Cur titulata diu; cessarunt iura sepulchri
msItem.explicit: 310 Marmore construxit; munus epitpahij

msItem.title: Epitaph of Johannis de Lignano
msItem.incipit: 310 ffrigida mirifici tenet hic lapis ossa Johannis
msItem.explicit: 310 Heu dolor hic mundus; portus et aura iacet

msItem.title: Satyrical poem against Pope Lucius III
msItem.author: Hugh Primas
msItem.incipit: 311 Lucius est piscis rex et tyrannus aquarum
msItem.explicit: 311 plus racionis habet ; qui racione caret

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.incipit: 311 ffelle bonus maculas illeso tolle colore
msItem.explicit: 311 his et lexiua (?) facta deletur amurca
msItem.note: This poem perhaps belongs to the previous poem.

msItem.title: Poem on absolution
msItem.rubric: 311 Casus in quibus communis sacerdos non potest absoluere
msItem.incipit: 311 Qui facit incestum deflorans aut homicida
msItem.explicit: 311 Pontificem super his semper deuotus adibit

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.incipit: 311 Magnus si[n]e paruus bonus et malus atque sinister
msItem.explicit: 311 Ista creant pariter inequalia comparatiua

msItem.title: Poem by John Whethamstede
msItem.incipit: 311 Laudis vix vnus vult successor dare munus
msItem.explicit: 311 Immo mihi qualis successor erit tibi talis
msItem.note: The same poem is attributed to John Whethamstede in the Annals of St Albans for the year 1438; see Riley, (1871), II: p. 202.

msItem.title: Verse from the Distichs of Cato
msItem.incipit: 311 Cum tibi displiceat rerum fortuna tuarum / Alterius specta quo sis discrimine peior
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.author: Peter of Blois
msItem.title: Excerpts from Peter of Blois, Compendium in Iob
msItem.rubric: 312 Petrus Blesensis super Job . io verbo Offerebat holocaust
msItem.incipit: 312 Illud pre ceteris michi materiam doloris importat, quod hodie viri religiosi et sancti ordinis professores de ferculorum numerositate et varietate contendunt
msItem.explicit: 312 non est hoc dicit do per prophetam ieiunium quod elegi etcaetera

msItem.title: Prayer to the Seven Archangels
msItem.rubric: Michael Gabriel Raphael Uriel Raguel Thobiel Barachiel
msItem.incipit: 312 Angele qui meus es custos pietate superna
msItem.explicit: 312 ante tribunal Christi me immaculatum valeat presentare. Per Christum

msItem.title: List of the sub-categories of vices and virtues
msItem.incipit: 313 Species luxurie: voluptas / Immunidicia / Turpiloquium
msItem.explicit: 313 veritas / lex / equitas. Explicit

msItem.title: Magical method for establishing how many men have had sexual intercourse with a woman
msItem.incipit: 312 Si vis scire quot voro [cypher for "viri"] substrauerunt mulierem mvloiri[m] [cypher for "mulierem"] scribe hec tria nomina cum in folio morelici cum s1ng4n2 [cypher for "sanguine"] v2sp2rt3l34n3s [cypher for "vespertilionis"] .aberis / abeis / asturias. ponatur quando est in summu super pectus. certum est.
msItem.note: This text is not noticed by M.R. James and has remained unencrypted until now. Words in the text have been encrypted in two ways: 1: The words viri and mulierem have been encoded by swapping their vowels with their next vowels in the alphabet (the letter that represents the sound "u" has not been replaced because it is written as a consonant v in the mansucript). 2: The words sanguine and vespertilionis have been encoded by replacing their vowels for numbers. Their numerical values are determined by their respective alphabetical order, i.e: a=1, e=2, i=3, and o=4.

msItem.title: Household recipes for making gum and dyeing hides or skins
msItem.incipit: 312 Take .iij. vncys of salpetre and an vnce of quyk brymston and an vnce of colys of salwh or of vyne tre þat is bettyr and braye þem to geder in a morter of bras . and est optimus pulius pro gumus
msItem.explicit: 312 Ȝif þou wylt make grene skynnys ; dyhte þy skynnys as is seyd by fore with alum . þanne take a quartrun of sal armonyak an nyh as myche of verdegrees and do þem in vynegre til þei be dyssolued and þan leye þat wit a brosche on þy skynnys etcaetera.

msItem.title: Letter of Darius to Alexander
msItem.incipit: 315 Darius rex regum et dominus dominantium Alexandro famulo meo
msItem.explicit: 315 qui te vinctum atque contumelisoe verberibus affectum; celsitudini nostre deducent

msItem.title: Letter of Alexander to Darius (reply)
msItem.incipit: 316 Rex alexander dario regi regum et dominantium dicit salutem
msItem.explicit: 316 Ideoque non abhorreas nec tibi durum uideatur tantum regem vt tu te iactas tantisque uiribus habundantem sub alexandro puero et latrocinante seruiturum

msItem.title: Verse
msItem.incipit: 316 Dignum sepui gens; tociens aquilam quoque fingens. / Vulpem nuluumque ; faceret qui viuit vtrumque
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.author: Marbod of Rennes
msItem.title: De Ornamentis Verborum
msItem.incipit: 317 Versificaturo quedam tibi tradere curo.
msItem.explicit: 318 O hector quondam troum fortissime frustra
msItem.note: This copy only represents only the first six stanzas of the full poem.

msItem.author: Attributed to "Hildebert" [probably Hildebert Le Mans] but written by Reginald of Canterbury
msItem.title: Poem on the Muses from the Vita Malchi
msItem.incipit: 318 Hildebertus in vita sancti malchi monachi quarto
msItem.explicit: 318 Caliope fari; pueros docet et modulari. hoc Hildebertus episcopus cenomanensis

msItem.author: Evrard de Béthune
msItem.title: Quatrain on the Muses and the liberal arts they invented from the Graecisimus
msItem.incipit: 318 Melpomone carmen inuenit . Tersicoreque [sic: Tersicoreusque] psalterium
msItem.explicit: 318 Ast vrania sit; que repperit astrologiam

msItem.title: Arithmetical questions in prose and verse
msItem.incipit: 319 Item quidam moriens habuit 9 sues quarum prima habuit unum porcellum, secunda duos, tertia tres, et sic de reliquis excedendo
msItem.explicit: 320 Item sit una quercus que habeat 12 ramos et quilibet ramus 12 apros et quilibet aper 12 strophas, et quelibet strophe 12 porcellos. Questio est quot sunt in numero, qualibetmultitudine. Respondeo: sunt apri 144, strophe 1728, porcelli 20736.

msItem.author: Ralph of Dunstable
msItem.title: Vita metrica sancti Albani
msItem.incipit: 321 Albani celebrem celo terrisque triumphum
msItem.explicit: 324 Hic probat hic cogit clamat hic esse nichil
msItem.note:
This is a previously unidentified, unfinished copy of Ralph of Dunstable's metrical life of St Alban. Three full-text copies of this work survive in:
Dublin, Trinity College Library, MS 177
London, British Library, Cotton MS Claudius E IV
London, British Library, Cotton MS Julius D I

msItem.title: Untitled poem
msItem.incipit: 324 Mus sine murilego miles sine principe. serus; absque metu domini. plebs sine lege furit
msItem.note: Full transcription; another copy of this poem occurs in Lincoln, Cathedral Library, MS 129.

msItem.title: Verses on things that are harmful to the eyes extracted from the Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 324 Alea vina venus ventus fala fumus et ignis. Caseus et fletus piper ictus cepe sinapis. Ista nocent oculis sed vigilare magis
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem, perhaps taken from the Cosmati Pavements at Westminster Abbey
msItem.rubric: 324 Si lector posita prudenter cuncta reuolua: hic finem primi mobilis inueniet
msItem.incipit: 324 Cepes trina canes et equos hominesque subaddis. / Ceruos et coruos aquilas et immania cete / Mundum quodque sequens preeuntem triplicat annos
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem about death
msItem.incipit: 324 Si dolor et lacrime morte reuocare valerent / Cerberus et pluto soli sua regna tenerent
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem about God's work
msItem.incipit: 324 Vinea culta fuit cultores permia querunt
msItem.explicit: 324 Illi seruire certi de munere sumis

msItem.title: Poem on transitoriness
msItem.incipit: 324 Quisquis ades qui morte cades . hoc perlege . plore. Sum quod eris, fueramque quod es, pro me precor ora. Vita breuis casusque leuis, nec spes remeandi. Plura seras vt plura feras , sit cura parandi.
msItem.note: Full transcription; the poem was perhaps taken from a funeral monument.

msItem.title: Poem on bad teachings
msItem.incipit: 324 Tortum rectificant distorquent recta fabules
msItem.explicit: 324 Sic fit pseudo gnato re cresus ore cato

msItem.title: Model letters
msItem.note: The letters have the following headings: Commissio ad generale consilium; Littera licentiatoria pro ordinibus recipiendis ; Littera ad citandum vel citatoria; Littera commisasoria ad recipiendam resignacionem vicarie (with other untitled letters).

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for dropsy and stomach pain: Pro ydropisi et malo stomacho.
One ingredient is given in Middle English: flour of canell.

msItem.title: Sequence of six prayers to Christ beginning with the letter 'O'
msItem.incipit: 331 Omni domine ihesu dulcissime memento quali amicitia
msItem.explicit: 331 et vt habeam cor benevolum ad queque bona paratum. amen

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.textLang: Latin instruction with names of herbs in Middle English
msItem.incipit: 331 Recipe semina istarum herbarum . loueache . smalache. waterkersyn
msItem.explicit: 331 galyngal . gynger . peper cloues . quibybys .ana ds vnce . lykorys quarter s. and ds vnce

msItem.title: Sequence of five prayers to Christ beginning with the letter 'D'
msItem.incipit: 332 Domine ihesu Christi rogo te per immensam dilectionem
msItem.explicit: 332 vt per teipsum et in teipso omnia mea sint suppleta coram patre tuo. amen
msItem.note: The same sequence occurs in Lucca, Biblioteca Statale di Lucca, MS 3540, ff. 129v–130r ; Powell, 'Biblioteca Statale di Lucca, ms 3540' (2019), pp. 46-47.

msItem.title: Sequence of five prayers to Christ beginning with the letter 'O'
msItem.incipit: 332 O dulcis ihesu salus et vita anime mee laduo et venior te in omnipotentia tua incomprehensibili
msItem.explicit: 333 vt possim eternam gehenne . amaritudinem feliciter en adere. amen. Pater [noster]. Aue

msItem.author: Mechtild of Hackeborn (visionary), but written down by two nuns of her community
msItem.title: Sequence of five prayers to Christ beginning with the letter 'D' based on the Liber Specialis Gratiae
msItem.incipit: 333 Dvlcissime domine ihesu Christe laudo et veneror te in vnione laudis tu
msItem.explicit: 334 sum factururus animabus fidelium cedant in salutem. amen
msItem.note: These prayers have been based on a vision of Mechtild of Hackeborn described in the Liber Specialis Gratiae, Book I, Chapter XLI.

msItem.author: Mechtild of Hackeborn (visionary), but written down by two nuns of her community
msItem.title: Sequence of five prayers to Christ beginning with the letter 'L' excerpted from the Liber Specialis Gratiae
msItem.incipit: 334 Laudo audoro magnifico glorifico et benedico te bone ihesu in illo ineffabili gaudio quod habuisti
msItem.explicit: 335 vt tuum gaudium et tuum bonum mecum sit hic et in eternum .amen. Dulcis ihesu
msItem.note: The same sequence occurs in Lucca, Biblioteca Statale di Lucca, MS 3540, ff. 127r-129r; see Powell (2022), p. 46.

msItem.title: Sequence of four prayers to the head and heart of Christ beginning with the letter 'S'
msItem.incipit: 335 Salue tremendum caput ihesu Christi etcaetera. Salue ihesu salue ihesu salue cor dulce ihesu dulcissimi
msItem.explicit: 335 in supplementum omnium bonorum que mihi desunt. amen. dulcis ihesu

msItem.author: Mechtild of Hackeborn (visionary), but written down by two nuns of her community
msItem.title: Sequence of five salutations to the Virgin Mary based on the Liber Specialis Gratiae
msItem.incipit: 335-336 Virgo gaude digna laude etcaetera. Ave maria mater dei et hominis in illa predulci susceptione qua in virginali puritate filium concepisti angelo nunciante et abbyssali humilitate tibi eum a regalibus sedibus intraxisti
msItem.explicit: 336 vt accedam ad dulcem ihesum filium tuum cum spirituali leticia. amen. ave maria. Tamquam sponsus
msItem.note: These prayers have been based on a vision of Mechtild of Hackeborn described in the Liber Specialis Gratiae, Book I, Chapter LVIII.

msItem.title: Suffrage to Christ
msItem.incipit: 333 Deus qui salutis eterne beate marie virginitate fecunda humano generi premia prestitisti tribue quaesumus vt ipsam pro nobis intercedere senciamus per quam meruimus auctorem vite suscipere ihesum Christum dominum nostrum
msItem.explicit: 336 Concede quaesumus omnipotens deus vt nos vnigeniti tui nova per carnem natiuitas liberet . quos sub peccati iugo vetusta seruitus tenet. Per eundem Christum.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Ave Maria
msItem.incipit: 336 Ave maria gracia plena
msItem.explicit: 336 et benedictus fructus ventris tui jhesus. Amen

msItem.title: Sequence of prayers for the Five Sorrows of the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: 336 Gaude maria quia cor tuum lancea nuditatis verecunde et viuperose erat affixum
msItem.explicit: 337 et consolatrix tuta in angustijs mortis mee. Post partum

msItem.title: Suffrage to Christ
msItem.incipit: 337 Graciam tuam quaesumus domine mentibus nostris infunde vt qui angelo nunciante Christi filij tui incarnacionem cognominus
msItem.explicit: 337 Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui humano generi ad imitandum humilitatis exemplum saluatorem nostrum carnem sumere et crucem subire fecisti concede propicius; vt e paciem ipsius habere documenta et resurreccionis consorcia mereamur . per eundem.

msItem.title: Mnemonic for an unfinished sequence of prayers to the Five Joys Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: 337 Gaude virgo
msItem.explicit: 337 Gaude quod post ipsum - Ubi fructu

msItem.title: Prayer to God
msItem.incipit: 338 Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui duina gabrielis salutacione et sancta filij tui natiuitate et gloriosa et admirandi eiusdem ascensione et veneranda ipsius genitricis sue assumpcione sancte marie matris tue gaudia contulisti presta quaesumus; vt pro eius amore ab omni specie doloris liberemur et sempiternis gaudiis perfrui mereamur. Per eundem [Christum dominum nostrum]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Mnemonic for a sequence of prayers to the Seven Celestial Joys of the Virgin Mary [sometimes attributed to Thomas of Canterbury]
msItem.incipit: 388 Gaude flore virginali honoreque speciali transcendens splendiferum angelorum principatum et sanctorum decoratum dignitate munerum
msItem.explicit: 388 Gaude virgo mater pura

msItem.title: Prayer to the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: 338 O sponsa dei electa mater domini nostri ihesu Christi benedicta esto nobis via recta ad eterna gaudia vbi pax est et gloria et nos semper aure pia dulcissima atque piissima exaudi virgo maria
msItem.note: Full transcription; this prayer belongs to the sequence of prayers to the Seven Celestial Joys of the Virgin Mary [previous item].

msItem.title: Prayer to Christ [Dulcissime domine Ihesu]
msItem.incipit: 338 Dulcissime domine Ihesu Christe qui beatissimam dei genitricem tuam gloriosam virginem Mariam perpetuis et felicibus gaudiis in celo letificasti concede propicius; vt eius meritis et precibus continuis salutem et prosperitatem mentis et corporis consequamur et ad gaudia tua et eius eterna feliciter perueniamus. Qui viuis [et regnas deus. Per omnis secula seculorum]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.author: Mechtild of Hackeborn (visionary), but written down by two nuns of her community
msItem.title: Sequence of prayers to the Five Joys of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, based on the Liber Specialis Gratiae, Book I, Chapter XL
msItem.incipit: 338 Gaude [maria] mater dulcis nati tui dulcis ihesu in illo ineffabili gaudio quod habuisti cum inaccessibile lumen beatissime trinitatis primo aspexisti in quo velut in speculo lucidissimo agnouisti illum eternum amorem
msItem.explicit: 339 et omne sanctorum gaudium de tua presencia augmentaretur [sic] Aue maria. assumpta est maria etcaetera

msItem.title: Suffrage to Christ
msItem.incipit: 339 Preces nostras quaesumus domine apud clemenciam tuam dei genitricis commendet oracio . quam iccirco de presenti seculo transtulisti . vt pro peccatis nostris apud de fiducialiter intercedat
msItem.explicit: 339 Concede quaesumus omnipotens deus vt qui vnigenitum tuum redemptorem noftrum ad celos ascendisse credimus . ipsi quoque mentem in celestibus habitemus per eundem
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Suffrage to Christ
msItem.incipit: 339 Preces nostras quaesumus domine apud clemenciam tuam dei genitricis commendet oracio . quam iccirco de presenti seculo transtulisti . vt pro peccatis nostris apud de fiducialiter intercedat
msItem.explicit: 339 Concede quaesumus omnipotens deus vt qui vnigenitum tuum redemptorem noftrum ad celos ascendisse credimus . ipsi quoque mentem in celestibus habitemus per eundem
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Sequence of fifteen prayers on the virtues of the Virgin Mary all beginning with "Salve maria mater ihesu virgo"
msItem.incipit: 340 Salue maria mater ihesu virgo dulcissima in amore seraphico quo deum per omni creatura dilexisti
msItem.explicit: 342 propter plagas ishesu Christ quas cruentas flens vidisti pro nostra miseria . fac me dignum te videre et videndo te gaudere ; in perhenni gloria nostra esto aduocata. et et ad regna duc beata per ihesum tuum filium. amen. Aue maria

msItem.title: The hymn Stella celi extirpavit presented as a prayer against the plague
msItem.incipit: 342 Stella celi extirpauit que lactauit dominum mortis pesttem quam plantauit primus parens hominum . Ipsa stella nunc dignetur sydera compescere ; quorum bella plebem cedunt dire mortis vlcere . versiculus. post partum . oracio. Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui gloriose virginis et matris etcatera
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Model letter
msItem.rubric: A littera manumissoria - Johannes vinfray filius Ricardi vinfray de [sic]

msItem.title: Model letter
msItem.note: Rubric only: the text is missing with the subsequent leaf.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in quires 2-21, consisting of a combination of an alphabetical letter ('a'-'y') and Roman numerals.

catchwords.seg: Occasional catchwords, one in a decorative banderol in brown ink.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Mainly single columns (except pp. 58 and 177 which have two columns; and 313 which has three columns). 21-24 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a cursive script with both Secretary and Anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Circle in red ink for an unfinished astronomical diagram on p. 306.
First letters of verse lines highlighted with red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

origin.note: Perhaps compiled over a longer period of time. John Whethamstede wrote his Granarium in the 1420s but was still updating the work in 1439. The epitaph of Thomas Godleef refers to the year 1445.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
